abstract: Study published in JAMA that analyzed 75 edible marijuana products available in Seattle, San Francisco and Los Angeles finds that 83 percent of them had labels that did not accurately describe their potency; 60 percent contained less THC, main psychoactive ingredient in marijuana, than advertised, while 23 percent contained more, which could pose problem for those who ingest products for medicinal benefits.
lead_paragraph: An analysis of 75 edible marijuana products found that labels on just 17 percent accurately described levels of THC, the main psychoactive ingredient.

headline.main: Edible Marijuana Labels Often Have Potency Wrong, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Edible Marijuana Labels Often Have Potency Wrong, Study Says

snippet: An analysis of 75 edible marijuana products found that labels on just 17 percent accurately described levels of THC, the main psychoactive ingredient.
